verses.text: In the seventh year of Jehu, Jehoash became king, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zibiah of Beersheba.
verses.comment: Jehoash (also called Joash) is presented as a legitimate Davidic king, with details that align with parallel accounts elsewhere, highlighting the continuity of the royal line from David (see 2 Samuel 7:12–16).

verses.text: Jehoash did what was right in the eyes of the LORD all his days, because Jehoiada the priest instructed him.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the king's faithfulness was closely tied to the guidance of the priest, highlighting the importance of spiritual authority and tradition in maintaining true worship (compare Deut. 17:18–20).

verses.text: Nevertheless, the high places were not taken away; the people still sacrificed and burned incense on the high places.
verses.comment: Despite reforms, imperfect obedience remains. True worship in Jerusalem's Temple is stressed, foreshadowing Christ as the fulfillment of all sacrifices (Heb. 10:12).

verses.text: Jehoash said to the priests, 'All the money of the holy things that is brought into the house of the LORD, the money for each person who passes the census, the money for the vows, and all the money that each person's heart prompts him to bring into the house of the LORD,
verses.comment: Jehoash organizes the temple funds, emphasizing the continuing role of freewill offerings and vows. This management of funds for worship anticipates the communal stewardship seen in the early Church (Acts 4:34-35).

verses.text: 'let the priests take it, each from his donors, and let them repair the house wherever any damage is found.'
verses.comment: The priests are made responsible for repairing the temple, showing the enduring link between priestly service and the sanctity of worship.

verses.text: But by the twenty-third year of King Jehoash, the priests had not repaired the damage of the house.
verses.comment: A delay in necessary repairs reveals human weakness, even among the leaders. It points to the need for ongoing reform and accountability, a perpetual challenge in the Church’s visible history.

verses.text: So King Jehoash called for Jehoiada the priest and the other priests and said to them, 'Why are you not repairing the damage to the house? Now take no more money from your donors, but give it for the repair of the house.'
verses.comment: The king asserts oversight over priestly administration – a unified cooperation between spiritual and civil authority, prefiguring the close relationship between Church and leadership in Christian history.

verses.text: So the priests agreed that they would not receive any more money from the people, nor repair the damage of the house themselves.
verses.comment: Priestly responsibility is redefined for effectiveness, pointing back to the principle that not all roles are interchangeable in God’s service (cf. Rom. 12:4-8).

verses.text: Then Jehoiada the priest took a chest, bored a hole in its lid, and set it beside the altar, on the right side as one enters the house of the LORD; and the priests who kept the threshold put in all the money that was brought into the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: This collection box marks a new, transparent way for gathering temple funds. This practice finds a parallel in Jesus' day with the treasury chests (Mark 12:41), showing the continuity of worship practices.

verses.text: Whenever they saw that there was much money in the chest, the king's secretary and the high priest came up, and they counted the money that was found in the house of the LORD and tied it up in bags.
verses.comment: Faithful management is emphasized by cooperation between royal and priestly authority, underscoring joint stewardship over offerings.

verses.text: Then they would deliver the money, weighed out, into the hands of those who did the work, who had the oversight of the house of the LORD. They paid it out to the carpenters and the builders who worked on the house of the LORD,
verses.comment: Careful distribution highlights accountability to God and the people, a key principle retained in the sacramental stewardship of the Church. The visible maintenance of God’s house points to the visible nature of God’s ongoing community.

verses.text: and to the masons and the stonecutters, and for buying timber and cut stone to repair the damage to the house of the LORD, and for all that was spent for the repairs of the house.
verses.comment: All skilled workers are needed for God’s house—anticipating the many parts that make up the Body of Christ (1 Cor. 12:12).

verses.text: But none of the money brought into the house of the LORD was used to make silver basins, snuffers, bowls, trumpets, any vessels of gold, or vessels of silver for the house of the LORD;
verses.comment: The focus here is on restoring the building rather than making new implements, showing the priority of a dwelling-place for God, foreshadowing Christ as the living temple (John 2:19-21).

verses.text: for they gave that to the workmen who repaired the house of the LORD with it.
verses.comment: Direct action and clear purpose were valued. Such renewal of the Lord’s house points to renewal through the sacraments and visible works of the people.

verses.text: They did not require an accounting from the men into whose hands they delivered the money to pay to those who did the work, for they dealt faithfully.
verses.comment: Remarkably, there’s trust in the integrity of the workers, reflecting the ideal for leaders and servants in spiritual matters (1 Tim. 3:2-7).

verses.text: The money for guilt offerings and for sin offerings was not brought into the house of the LORD; it was for the priests.
verses.comment: Offerings designated for atonement remained with the priests, showing the distinct roles for clergy and laity—a pattern that continues throughout Redemptive history.

verses.text: Then Hazael king of Aram went up and fought against Gath and captured it. Then Hazael set his face to go up against Jerusalem.
verses.comment: This external threat fulfills warnings about judgment when Israel faltered from full covenant obedience (Deut. 28:25).

verses.text: Jehoash, king of Judah, took all the sacred things that Jehoshaphat and Jehoram and Ahaziah, his fathers, kings of Judah, had dedicated, and his own sacred things, and all the gold that was found in the treasuries of the house of the LORD and the king's house, and sent it to Hazael king of Aram. Then he withdrew from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Though the treasures are used to protect the nation, it foreshadows the later spoiling of the temple. Only the true, eternal sanctuary—and the true “treasures”—can never be taken away (Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Jehoash, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the kings of Judah?
verses.comment: The inspired text points to historical sources, confirming the reliability of tradition as a witness to God’s works in history.

verses.text: His servants arose and made a conspiracy, and killed Jehoash in the house of Millo, on the way that goes down to Silla.
verses.comment: Even kings are subject to betrayal and death. This anticipates in shadow the betrayal of Christ (Luke 22:48), though in Christ’s case, it brings ultimate victory.

verses.text: For Jozacar the son of Shimeath and Jehozabad the son of Shomer, his servants, struck him down, and he died. So they buried him with his fathers in the city of David, and Amaziah his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: The Davidic line persists despite the king’s death. God’s faithfulness to his promises is evident in the continuation of the line, which ultimately leads to Christ, the true King (Matt. 1:6).
